speaker: Viral image
vclaim: It says a deer that became "filled with a tumor of food plants sprayed on Monsanto's tour."
date: stated on May 8, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: The tumor on the deer in the viral image was not caused by Monsanto's meeting.
text: A disturbing picture of a white-tailed gazelle covered by a large tumor has returned to social media tours. The text above the picture says: "The deer has become full of tumors from eating plants that have been sprayed on Monsanto's tour. Seems rather common." The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) The hairless prosthetics are called Maas Cataños, commonly referred to as deer bull, and are found in deer herds in the majority of the United States, according to the report of the Mississippi Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks Administration. As a result, according to the organization, warts are considered to exist in the entire range of white-tailed deer. But such limes are not caused by the Monsanto Tour, or by any other herbicide. The warts are the result of a viral infection that is believed to be transmitted through different bites. The viral agent may also be transmitted through direct contact with the affected skin. Once the virus enters the skin, the warts were found to form within seven weeks. The disease is no longer temporary either, as researchers say, and lasts about two months before it begins to decline in most deer. Kevin Haynes, a wildlife biologist in the New York Conservation Department, confirmed to Bolivac by e-mail that the proteins in the picture are actually LEMA. "It's fairly common in the N.Y. and it's caused by a virus that spreads through bites or through direct contact; the virus does not infect humans or pets," Heinz's books. "The fungi are usually found in younger deer and usually retreat, drying and falling and leaving no evidence of their presence there. Viproma does not cause deer problems unless the eyes cover or are very large and/or numerous (as in your image) and have second-degree bacteria." While their appearance may be awful, the levees usually do not harm deer, according to a 2011 publication of the National Wildlife Research Centre of the Ministry of Agriculture. However, the report states that deer with heavy tumor loads may suffer from "exhaustion and disability due to tumors, interference with vision, breathing, ingestion of food, and movement." Sometimes, researchers say, vibrium can create bacterial infection. While our efforts to find the origin of this image using the search for reverse images were inconclusive, the fact-finding website reported that it first appeared on the Facebook page of fishermen in an article that went on the real cause of growth. Regardless of origin, we know that the image shows deer with growth that appears to be consistent with a situation commonly known as deer-wearing. The allegation that such defects are caused by a herbicide is not true. We value this allegation wrong. Sharing the facts 2019-05-20 14:52:34 UTC PoliticFact 2 1 7 PoliticFact Rating: Falsely says that a deer became "filled with a tumor of plants sprayed by the Monsanto Tour." The online viral image of Wednesday, 8 May 2019, 2019-05-08, read more information.
